title: Quiz 13: Immunology
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions
description: Immunology MCQs covering innate and adaptive immunity, cell types, antibodies, and immune responses.

questions.question: A patient is exposed to the hepatitis B virus (HBV) and develops immunity against future infections. Which type of immunity is primarily responsible for this protection?
questions.explanation: Humoral immunity involves the production of antibodies (immunoglobulins) by B cells, which circulate in the blood and protect against specific pathogens like viruses upon re-exposure.
questions.hint: This type involves B-cells and antibodies.

questions.question: Which of the following cell types is primarily responsible for presenting antigens to T cells during the immune response?
questions.explanation: Macrophages are key Antigen-Presenting Cells (APCs) that phagocytose pathogens and display their antigens on MHC molecules to T cells.
questions.hint: These 'big eaters' show what they've eaten to T cells.

questions.question: A patient with a severe bacterial infection has elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) in their blood. Which of the following functions does CRP primarily serve during the acute phase response?
questions.explanation: CRP binds to the surface of dead or dying cells and some bacteria, acting as an opsonin to activate the complement system and enhance phagocytosis.
questions.hint: It coats the pathogen to make it 'tasty' for phagocytes.

questions.question: Which of the following types of T cells is primarily involved in the regulation of the immune response by suppressing excessive inflammation and preventing autoimmunity?
questions.explanation: Regulatory T cells (Tregs) play a crucial role in maintaining tolerance to self-antigens and abrogating autoimmune disease by suppressing immune responses.
questions.hint: These cells 'regulate' or dampen the immune system.

questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the phenomenon of immunological memory, wherein the immune system mounts a faster and more robust response upon re-exposure to a previously encountered pathogen?

options.text: Clonal expansion of memory B cells
Differentiation of naïve T cells into effector T cells
Production of antibodies by plasma cells

questions.explanation: Memory B cells persist after an infection. Upon re-exposure, they rapidly proliferate (clonal expansion) and differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells.
questions.hint: Specific cells 'remember' the antigen and multiply rapidly.

questions.question: A patient with a severe fungal infection demonstrates impaired neutrophil function. Which of the following cellular processes is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.explanation: Neutrophils are the primary phagocytes of the innate immune system, responsible for ingesting (phagocytosis) and destroying pathogens like fungi.
questions.hint: Neutrophils 'eat' pathogens.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of natural killer (NK) cells in the immune response?

options.text: NK cells directly kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells.
NK cells produce antibodies against pathogens.
NK cells present antigens to T cells to initiate adaptive immunity.
NK cells release cytokines to recruit other immune cells to the site of infection.

questions.explanation: NK cells recognize and destroy stressed cells (viral-infected or tumor) without prior sensitization (innate immunity).
questions.hint: They kill abnormal host cells directly.

questions.question: Which of the following cytokines is primarily responsible for promoting differentiation of naïve T cells into Th1 cells and enhancing cell-mediated immune responses?
questions.explanation: IFN-gamma is the signature cytokine of the Th1 response, driving cell-mediated immunity against intracellular pathogens.
questions.hint: This interferon is crucial for Th1 dominance.

questions.question: A patient presents with symptoms of severe allergies, including difficulty breathing, hives, and swelling. Which of the following cells is primarily responsible for mediating these allergic responses?
questions.explanation: Mast cells release histamine and other mediators when IgE binds to allergens, causing the symptoms of anaphylaxis and allergy.
questions.hint: These cells are packed with histamine granules.

questions.question: Which of the following immunoglobulin classes is primarily involved in providing passive immunity to newborn infants through breast milk?
questions.explanation: Secretory IgA is found in high concentrations in colostrum and breast milk, protecting the infant's gastrointestinal tract.
questions.hint: This Ig is found in secretions like breast milk.

questions.question: A patient with a chronic viral infection demonstrates persistently elevated levels of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells in their blood. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this observation?
questions.explanation: In chronic viral infections, constant antigen stimulation can lead to T cell exhaustion, where cells persist but lose function.
questions.hint: The cells are tired from fighting a chronic infection.

questions.question: Which of the following cell types is primarily responsible for the production of antibodies during the humoral immune response?
questions.explanation: Plasma cells are differentiated B cells that specialize in the mass production and secretion of antibodies.
questions.hint: These are the 'antibody factories' of the immune system.

questions.question: A patient with a suspected autoimmune disorder exhibits antibodies directed against self-antigens, leading to tissue damage and inflammation. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the development of autoimmune diseases?
questions.explanation: Autoimmunity results from a breakdown in the mechanisms that normally prevent the immune system from attacking the body's own tissues (loss of self-tolerance).
questions.hint: The body forgets what is 'self' vs 'non-self'.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of dendritic cells in the immune response?

options.text: Dendritic cells directly kill infected cells and tumor cells.
Dendritic cells produce antibodies against pathogens.
Dendritic cells activate naïve T cells and initiate adaptive immune responses.
Dendritic cells release histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

questions.explanation: Dendritic cells are the most potent professional Antigen-Presenting Cells (APCs) capable of activating naïve T cells, bridging innate and adaptive immunity.
questions.hint: They are professional antigen presenters.

questions.question: A patient with a severe viral infection exhibits reduced levels of circulating lymphocytes. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this observation?

options.text: Clonal expansion of memory T cells
Upregulation of adhesion molecules on lymphocytes

questions.explanation: During infection, lymphocytes upregulate adhesion molecules to migrate (margination/extravasation) out of the blood and into the tissues/lymph nodes to fight infection, leading to a temporary drop in blood count.
questions.hint: The cells leave the blood to go to the site of infection.

questions.question: Which of the following cell types is primarily responsible for secreting pro-inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-1 (IL-1) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) during the acute phase response?
questions.explanation: Activated macrophages are the primary source of IL-1 and TNF-alpha, which orchestrate the acute inflammatory response.
questions.hint: These cells are the first responders in tissues that signal for help.

questions.question: Which of the following immune cells is primarily responsible for coordinating and regulating immune responses by producing cytokines that direct the activities of other immune cells?
questions.explanation: CD4+ Helper T cells act as the 'generals' of the immune system, directing the response via cytokine signaling to B cells, CTLs, and macrophages.
questions.hint: They 'help' other cells know what to do.

questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the generation of diversity in the antigen-binding sites of immunoglobulins?
questions.explanation: V(D)J recombination (gene rearrangement) in the bone marrow creates the vast diversity of initial antibody specificities.
questions.hint: It involves shuffling DNA segments.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules in antigen presentation?

options.text: MHC class I molecules present exogenous antigens to CD4+ T cells.
MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells.
MHC class II molecules present endogenous antigens to CD4+ T cells.
MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells.

questions.explanation: Rule of 8: MHC I x CD8 = 8 (Endogenous/Intracellular pathway). MHC II x CD4 = 8 (Exogenous/Extracellular pathway).
questions.hint: Remember the 'Rule of 8' (1x8=8).

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the process of opsonization during the immune response?

options.text: Opsonins facilitate the lysis of target cells by forming membrane attack complexes.
Opsonins promote the phagocytosis of pathogens by coating them with proteins.
Opsonins neutralize toxins produced by pathogens.
Opsonins stimulate the release of histamine from mast cells.

questions.explanation: Opsonization coats pathogens with proteins (antibodies or complement) to make them easier for phagocytes to bind and ingest.
questions.hint: It makes the pathogen 'tasty' for phagocytes.

questions.question: A patient is diagnosed with selective IgA deficiency, a primary immunodeficiency disorder. Which of the following complications is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: IgA protects mucous membranes. Deficiency leads to recurrent sino-pulmonary and GI infections.
questions.hint: Think about where IgA is usually found (mucosa).

questions.question: A patient with a history of multiple myeloma demonstrates hypogammaglobulinemia. Which of the following immunoglobulin classes is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation: IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in serum. In myeloma, production of normal functional immunoglobulins (especially IgG) is suppressed.
questions.hint: This is the most abundant antibody in the blood.

questions.question: A patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) demonstrates a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test and elevated levels of anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the production of these autoantibodies?
questions.explanation: SLE is the prototype autoimmune disease caused by a loss of tolerance to nuclear self-antigens.
questions.hint: Repeated concept: The body attacks itself.

questions.question: Which of the following terms refers to the process by which antibodies coat the surface of pathogens, marking them for destruction by phagocytes or complement proteins?
questions.explanation: This is the definition of opsonization.
questions.hint: From the Greek word for 'to make tasty'.

questions.question: Which of the following cellular receptors is responsible for recognizing pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and initiating innate immune responses?
questions.explanation: TLRs are key Pattern Recognition Receptors (PRRs) of the innate immune system that detect conserved pathogen structures (PAMPs).
questions.hint: These receptors act as 'tolls' or gateways to the innate response.
